subject: Re: [junit] Basic Doubt

But you do need to instantiate the Manager object at some point. If more 
test methods are going to use the Manager then instantiating in the 
setUp method will make it available to every test method: setUp is 
called before any test method is called, as well tearDown is called at 
the end of every test method.

However, in this case you aren't even using the Manager object. I 
recommend you read the cookbook (available on the JUnit site) which is 
sort of a "Getting Started" guide.

Jason

Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> On 6/27/06, strutsquery <strutsquery@... 
> <mailto:strutsquery%40yahoo.co.in>> wrote:
>
> > Why is the Manager object required to be instantiated inside the
> > setUp method?
>
> It's not.
>
> Is it required to have a test suite method?
>
> No, but your code should work fine, just remove the call to testAdd() in
> your setUp() method, JUnit will invoke testAdd() on its own.
>
> -- 
> Cédric
> http://testng.org <http://testng.org>
